Abstract

We discuss the possible existence of the fully-heavy tetraquarks. We calculate the ground-state energy of the bâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘bb\bar{b}\bar{b} bound state, where bğ‘b stands for the bottom quark, in a nonrelativistic effective field theory framework with one-gluon-exchange (OGE) color Coulomb interaction, and in a relativized diquark model characterized by OGE plus a confining potential. Our analysis advocates the existence of uni-flavor heavy four-quark bound states. The ground state bâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘bb\bar{b}\bar{b} tetraquark mass is predicted to be (18.72Â±0.02)plus-or-minus18.720.02(18.72\pm 0.02)Â GeV. Mass inequality relations among the lowest Qâ€‹Qâ€‹QÂ¯â€‹QÂ¯ğ‘„ğ‘„Â¯ğ‘„Â¯ğ‘„QQ\bar{Q}\bar{Q} state, where Qâˆˆ{c,b}ğ‘„ğ‘ğ‘Q\in\{c,b\}, and the corresponding heavy quarkonia are presented, which give the upper limit on the mass of ground state Qâ€‹Qâ€‹QÂ¯â€‹QÂ¯ğ‘„ğ‘„Â¯ğ‘„Â¯ğ‘„QQ\bar{Q}\bar{Q}. The possible decays of the lowest bâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘bb\bar{b}\bar{b} are highlighted, which might provide useful references in the search for them in ongoing LHC experiments, and its width is estimated to be a few tens of MeV.

I Introduction

Heavy quarkonium spectroscopy is the arena of quark potential models, in which the full interaction incorporates the short-range one-gluon-exchange (OGE) and long-range confining potentialÂ Eichten:1978tg ; Richardson:1978bt ; Buchmuller:1980su ; Godfrey:1985xj ; Barnes:2005pb . To put heavy quarkonium spectroscopy in a model-independent framework, efforts have been made to develop a nonrelativistic effective field theory formalismÂ Pineda:1997bj ; Brambilla:1999xf ; Brambilla:2004jw .

Higher-order perturbative calculations show that the lowest-lying heavy quarkonia can be assigned as weakly coupled statesÂ Pineda:1997hz ; Brambilla:1999xj ; Kniehl:2002br . They are characterized by a momentum scale mâ€‹vâ‰«Î›QCDmuch-greater-thanğ‘šğ‘£subscriptÎ›QCDmv\gg\Lambda_{\rm QCD}, where mğ‘šm and vğ‘£v are the heavy quark mass and velocity, respectively, and Î›QCDsubscriptÎ›QCD\Lambda_{\rm QCD} is the nonperturbative scale of quantum chromodynamics (QCD), and their dynamics is mainly dominated by the short-distance interaction. In particular, there is some evidence that the first few bottomonia and Bcsubscriptğµğ‘B_{c} mesons can be identified as weakly coupled systemsÂ Titard:1993nn ; Brambilla:2000db ; Brambilla:2001fw , while the J/Ïˆğ½ğœ“J/\psi lies on the borderline of this classificationÂ Brambilla:2004jw . The lowest-lying doubly- and triply-heavy baryons have also been studied as weakly coupled bound statesÂ Brambilla:2005yk ; Jia:2006gw but, due to the lack of experimental incentive,111Very recently, the LHCb Collaboration announced the first measurement of the Sğ‘†S-wave doubly-charm baryon, the Îcâ€‹c++superscriptsubscriptÎğ‘ğ‘absent\Xi_{cc}^{++}Â Aaij:2017ueg , with a mass of about 3620Â MeV. this area is not as well explored as that of heavy quarkonia.

It is also worth mentioning some recent indications of the existence of mesons whose properties and quantum numbers do not fit into a traditional quarkonium interpretation (for recent reviews, seeÂ Nakamura:2010zzi ; Brambilla:2014jmp ; Chen:2016qju ; Lebed:2016hpi ; Esposito:2016noz ; Guo:2017jvc ; Ali:2017jda ; Olsen:2017bmm ). These states, including Zbâ€‹(10610)subscriptğ‘ğ‘10610Z_{b}(10610) and Zbâ€‹(10650)subscriptğ‘ğ‘10650Z_{b}(10650)Â Bondar , Zcâ€‹(3900)subscriptğ‘ğ‘3900Z_{c}(3900)Â Ablikim ; Liu , and Zcâ€‹(4025)subscriptğ‘ğ‘4025Z_{c}(4025)Â Ablikim2 , have similar features and must be made up of four valence quarks, as they are isovector states in the heavy quarkonium mass region. Another interesting example is Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872)Â Choi:2003ue which, because of its unusual properties, does not fit well into a pure charmonium pictureÂ Godfrey:1985xj ; Eichten:1978tg ; Barnes:2005pb . Several alternative interpretations have been proposedÂ Hanhart:2007yq ; Baru:2011rs ; Swanson:2003tb ; Pennington:2007xr ; Li:2009ad ; Danilkin:2010cc ; charmonium ; Maiani:2004vq .

Fully-heavy tetraquarks, such as bâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘bb\bar{b}\bar{b} and the charm analog câ€‹câ€‹cÂ¯â€‹cÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘cc\bar{c}\bar{c}, are of considerable interest, since they are free of light degrees of freedom and might be used as an elegant probe to investigate the interplay between both aspects of QCD: perturbative and nonperturbative. Owing to the lack of experimental incentive, only a few theoretical studies have been conducted in this field, and whether Nature allows the bound states of fully-heavy tetraquarks or not is still an open question. If it does, what are their masses and decay properties? Recently, this debate has given rise to several studies within different approaches, including the constituent quark and diquark modelÂ Bai:2016int ; Eichten:2017ual ; Karliner:2016zzc ; Berezhnoy:2011xn , chiral quark modelÂ Wu:2016vtq , chromo-electric potential modelÂ Richard:2017vry , and QCD sum rulesÂ Chen:2016jxd ; Wang:2017jtz . All of these predict the existence of fully-heavy (bottom) tetraquarks, except for Ref.Â Richard:2017vry , in which the authors argue that the stability of a fully-heavy system of quarks should rely on more subtle effects that are not included in the simple picture of constituent quarks. The fully-heavy tetraquark case is similar to that of polyelectrons Ps2subscriptPs2\textrm{Ps}_{2}, the bound state of two electrons and two positrons (eâˆ’â€‹eâˆ’â€‹e+â€‹e+superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘’e^{-}e^{-}e^{+}e^{+}), discussed long ago by WheelerÂ Wheeler:1946zz . Just after the prediction of Ps2subscriptPs2\textrm{Ps}_{2}, a debate on their stability started Ore:1946zz ; Hylleraas:1947zza , but it took half a century to get experimental evidence of themÂ Nature:2007 .

In this paper, we compute the bâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground-state energy. The calculations are performed within the formalism of a nonrelativistic effective field theory (NREFT) at the leading order (LO), which neglects all spin-dependent and confining interactions, and in a relativized diquark-antidiquark model, both of which are characterized by the OGE potential. We also make a rough estimate of the bâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘bb\bar{b}\bar{b} total width, in order to guide experimental searches.

The paper is organized as follows. In sectionÂ II, we describe the NREFT approach to solve the system considered. At the end of this section, we include our diquark model results. SectionÂ III is devoted to discussing the results, and we compare our predictions of the mass of the Xbâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘X_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}} ground-state with those of previous studies. In SectionÂ IV, we derive a set of mass inequalities, and provide the upper limits of the ground state masses of several fully-heavy tetraquarks. In Sec.Â V, we highlight some possible decay modes of the Xbâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘X_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}} and give the ballpark estimate of its total decay width. Finally, we provide a short summary.

II Formalism

In this section, we describe an NREFT approach to the fully-heavy tetraquark spectroscopy, characterized by the OGE interaction. This is used to estimate the mass of the bâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground state. As all of the four quarks are very heavy, the tetraquark system is weakly coupled with a small size of the order 1/(mQâ€‹Î±s)âˆ¼1/(mQâ€‹v)similar-to1subscriptğ‘šğ‘„subscriptğ›¼ğ‘ 1subscriptğ‘šğ‘„ğ‘£1/(m_{Q}\alpha_{s})\sim 1/(m_{Q}v), where vâ‰ª1much-less-thanğ‘£1v\ll 1 is the heavy quark velocity. In this case, the dynamics of the system is dominated by the OGE which provides a color Coulomb potential at the LO, and the long-distance confining potential and spin-dependent interactions become perturbations.

In addition, we also give a tetraquark (diquark-antidiquark) model prediction for the bâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground-state mass.

II.2 Solving the four-body problem

The four-body problem is notoriously delicate. One should be careful about the choice of the wave functions, because a crude adoption may give rise to misleading conclusions, as first illustrated by Ore in 1946 in Ref. Ore:1946zz in the case of polyelectrons (eâˆ’â€‹eâˆ’â€‹e+â€‹e+superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘’e^{-}e^{-}e^{+}e^{+} bound states). One year later the author, in collaboration with HylleraasÂ Hylleraas:1947zza , came up with an elegant prescription to handle four-body systems. This is what we are willing to use to calculate the bâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground-state energy, provided that we make the substitution eâˆ’â†’bâ†’superscriptğ‘’ğ‘e^{-}\rightarrow b, e+â†’bÂ¯â†’superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğ‘e^{+}\rightarrow\bar{b}.

Since the ground state is non-degenerate and its symmetries are governed by those of the Hamiltonian â„‹NRsuperscriptâ„‹NR\mathcal{H}^{\rm NR}, the spatial wave function should be symmetric under the exchange of Q1â€‹Q2â†”QÂ¯3â€‹QÂ¯4â†”subscriptğ‘„1subscriptğ‘„2subscriptÂ¯ğ‘„3subscriptÂ¯ğ‘„4Q_{1}Q_{2}\leftrightarrow\bar{Q}_{3}\bar{Q}_{4}. This leads to Ïˆspatialâ€‹(Q1â€‹Q2)=Ïˆspatialâ€‹(QÂ¯3â€‹QÂ¯4)subscriptğœ“spatialsubscriptğ‘„1subscriptğ‘„2subscriptğœ“spatialsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘„3subscriptÂ¯ğ‘„4\psi_{\textrm{spatial}}(Q_{1}Q_{2})=\psi_{\textrm{spatial}}(\bar{Q}_{3}\bar{Q}_{4}). This symmetryÂ Hylleraas:1947zza helps to reduce the number of integration variables and simplify the four-body problem. To describe the quark relative motion, we define the following Jacobi coordinates,

II.4 bâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground state in a relativized diquark model

In this subsection, we provide an estimate of the fully-bottom tetraquark ground-state energy by treating the Xbâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘X_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}} configuration as a diquark, bâ€‹bğ‘ğ‘bb, and antidiquark, bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘\bar{b}\bar{b}, bound state in a relativized diquark model. In this model, the diquark is an effective degree of freedom which describes two strongly correlated quarks with no internal spatial excitations. The lowest-energy diquark configurations, scalar and axial-vector, are both color anti-triplets but have different spin and flavor quantum numbers. The former, i.e., the scalar diquark, has spin-0 and its flavor wave function is antisymmetric. The latter has spin-1 and is flavor-symmetric. As mentioned in the last section, because of the Pauli principle, a (point-like) diquark made up of quarks of the same flavor can only be of the axial-vector type Debastiani:2017msn ; Jaffe:2004ph .

To calculate the energy of the bâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground state in diquark anti-diquark configuration, we need an evaluation of the bâ€‹bğ‘ğ‘bb axial-vector diquark mass, Mav,bâ€‹bsubscriptğ‘€avğ‘ğ‘M_{{\rm av},bb}. The diquark (antidiquark) mass is estimated by binding a bâ€‹bğ‘ğ‘bb (bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘\bar{b}\bar{b}) pair via the OGE plus a confining potentialÂ Godfrey:1985xj , and we have444Notice that the parameters in this diquark model are different from those in the NREFT approach.

Mav,bâ€‹b=9.85â€‹GeV.subscriptğ‘€avğ‘ğ‘9.85GeVM_{{\rm av},bb}=9.85~{}{\rm GeV}. (14)

After doing that, we can compute the 1â€‹S1ğ‘†1S, 0++superscript0absent0^{++} tetraquark ground-state energy in the relativized diquark model. The model Hamiltonian is characterized by the OGE plus confining potential. For more details on the model and the values of the model parameters, we refer to Ref.Â Anwar:2018sol . With the use of the previous value of Mav,bâ€‹bsubscriptğ‘€avğ‘ğ‘M_{{\rm av},bb}, we get

Mbâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯gs,REL=18.75â€‹Â GeV,superscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘gsREL18.75Â GeVM_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}}^{\rm gs,REL}=18.75\mbox{ GeV}\,, (15)

which is consistent with the result obtained in the previous subsection. See also TableÂ 1, where our relativized diquark model prediction is compared to those of previous studies. The theoretical uncertainty in the above prediction can be estimated by using the typical error of the quark model calculations. The intrinsic error in the quark model predictions is of the order of 30âˆ¼50similar-to305030\sim 50 MeVÂ charmonium ; therefore, this diquark model prediction has the cumulative uncertainty of ğ’ªâ€‹(50â€‹MeV)ğ’ª50MeV\mathcal{O}(50~{}\textrm{MeV}).

III Results and Discussion

In TableÂ 1, our NREFT and relativized diquark model results for the mass of the bâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground-state are compared with those of previous studies. The results are strongly model-dependent and vary in the range of (18.7Â±0.2)plus-or-minus18.70.2(18.7\pm 0.2)Â GeV, approximately. The differences among the results mainly stem from different choices of effective Hamiltonians, the model-parameter fitting procedures, and the use of distinct approximations in the tetraquark wave function. This last is related to the possible ways of combining the quark color representations to obtain a color singlet wave function for the tetraquark. In the last column of the table, we also report the differences between the predicted masses and the Î·bâ€‹Î·bsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘subscriptğœ‚ğ‘\eta_{b}\eta_{b} threshold, (18798Â±4)plus-or-minus187984(18798\pm 4)Â MeVÂ Nakamura:2010zzi whose central value is used.

It is worthwhile to remind some previous studies. For example, KarlinerÂ et al.Â Karliner:2016zzc made a phenomenological estimation of the Qâ€‹Qâ€‹QÂ¯â€‹QÂ¯ğ‘„ğ‘„Â¯ğ‘„Â¯ğ‘„QQ\bar{Q}\bar{Q} ground-state energies, with Q=bğ‘„ğ‘Q=b and cğ‘c. The authors utilized a relation between meson and baryon masses to extrapolate the binding energy of Qâ€‹Qâ€‹QÂ¯â€‹QÂ¯ğ‘„ğ‘„Â¯ğ‘„Â¯ğ‘„QQ\bar{Q}\bar{Q} systems in the diquark model. They made the ballpark estimates of Bbâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹(1â€‹S)subscriptğµğ‘Â¯ğ‘1ğ‘†B_{b\bar{b}}(1S) and the binding energy of the tetraquark with respect to the two-bâ€‹bğ‘ğ‘bb-diquark threshold, and obtained a value of about 1/2121/2 for the ratio Bbâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹(1â€‹S)/Bbâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯â€‹(1â€‹S)subscriptğµğ‘Â¯ğ‘1ğ‘†subscriptğµğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘1ğ‘†{B_{b\bar{b}}(1S)}/{B_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}}(1S)}.

BaiÂ et al. calculated the bâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground-state energy by means of a phenomenological potential, whose parameters were fitted to the bâ€‹bÂ¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘b\bar{b} spectrum and verified by lattice simulationÂ Bai:2016int . The bâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground-state energy was obtained by solving the SchrÃ¶dinger equation numerically; spin-dependent corrections and a linear confining potential were included. Their result agrees with our LO NREFT result very well, indicating that neglecting the spin-dependent and confining parts provides a very good approximation to the system under study.

A diquark model prediction of the bâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘bb\bar{b}\bar{b} and câ€‹câ€‹cÂ¯â€‹cÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘cc\bar{c}\bar{c} ground-state energies was given in Ref.Â Berezhnoy:2011xn . There, the authors assumed tetraquarks to be made up of two almost point-like diquarks in the color-triplet configuration. The model parameters were fitted by solving a non-relativistic SchrÃ¶dinger equation for the charmonium and bottomonium spectrum. The bâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground-state mass agrees with our diquark model well.

In Ref.Â Ader:1981db , the authors computed the câ€‹câ€‹cÂ¯â€‹cÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘cc\bar{c}\bar{c} ground-state energy within a nonrelativistic potential model. The authors concluded that the possibility of obtaining bound states depends on the assumptions made on the quark dynamics and the flavor configurations. There are also early predictions for the massÂ Iwasaki:1975pv and widthÂ chao:1981 of the fully-charm tetraquark, and the ground-state energies of Q2â€‹QÂ¯2superscriptğ‘„2superscriptÂ¯ğ‘„2Q^{2}\bar{Q}^{2} systems, with Qâˆˆ{s,c,b,t}ğ‘„ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡Q\in\{s,c,b,t\}Â heller:1985 . For the full mass spectrum of all-charm tetraquarks, we refer to Ref.Â Debastiani:2017msn . All-charm four-quark bound state has also been studied in the Betheâ€“Salpeter approach and the ground state was reported to be deeply bound (650 MeV) below the 2â€‹Î·c2subscriptğœ‚ğ‘2\eta_{c} thresholdÂ Heupel:2012ua .

A study of the importance of mixing effects between tetraquark and molecular-type components is also worthwhile to be carried out, especially for those states which are close to meson-meson thresholds. The probability of a fully-heavy tetraquark to be a (Qâ€‹QÂ¯)âˆ’(Qâ€‹QÂ¯)ğ‘„Â¯ğ‘„ğ‘„Â¯ğ‘„(Q\bar{Q})-(Q\bar{Q}) hadronic molecule might be calculable without any ambiguity. It is worthwhile to mention that the possibility of an Î·bsubscriptğœ‚b\eta_{\rm b}-Î·bsubscriptğœ‚b\eta_{\rm b} bound state has been studied by computing the QCD van der Vaals force in the framework of potential nonrelativistic QCD in Ref.Â Brambilla:2016 . Given that the recent lattice nonrelativistic QCD calculation did not find any state below the noninteracting Î·bâ€‹Î·bsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘subscriptğœ‚ğ‘\eta_{b}\eta_{b} thresholdÂ Hughes:2017xie , such a study seems necessary to understand what happens.

It would also be very interesting to test the possibility of a bâ€‹bâ€‹cÂ¯â€‹cÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘bb\bar{c}\bar{c} tetraquark that remains stable against strong decays,555All the other possible fully-heavy tetraquarks can decay strongly by annihilating at least a pair of quarks and antiquarks of the same flavor. but unfortunately there is no experimental evidence yet. The stability of heavy-light tetraquark systems is still an open question. The Qâ€‹Qâ€‹qÂ¯â€‹qÂ¯ğ‘„ğ‘„Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘QQ\bar{q}\bar{q} was shown to be stable against strong decays by Lipkin long ago666Before Lipkin, the authors of Ref.Â Ader:1981db also argued that XQâ€‹Qâ€‹qÂ¯â€‹qÂ¯subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘„ğ‘„Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘X_{QQ\bar{q}\bar{q}} is stable if the quark mass ratio mQ/mqsubscriptğ‘šğ‘„subscriptğ‘šğ‘m_{Q}/m_{q} is large enough. Very recently, bâ€‹bâ€‹qÂ¯â€‹qÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘bb\bar{q}\bar{q} was shown to be stable against strong decays but not its charm counterpart câ€‹câ€‹qÂ¯â€‹qÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘cc\bar{q}\bar{q}, nor the mixed (beauty+charm) bâ€‹câ€‹qÂ¯â€‹qÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘bc\bar{q}\bar{q} stateÂ Karliner:2017qjm ; Eichten:2017ffp . IV Tetraquark-Meson Mass Inequalities

One can estimate the lower bounds of the ground state energy levels of the fully-heavy four-quark systems by using the variational approach, as suggested long ago by NussinovÂ Nussinov:1983vh and by Bertlmann and MartinÂ Bertlmann:1979zs . This approach was tested by the lattice QCD calculations of WeingartenÂ Weingarten:1983uj and also by the rigorous calculations in the vectorlike gauge theories (QCD) by WittenÂ Witten:1983ut . We attempt to extend Nussinovâ€™s approach to the fully-heavy four-quark bound states and obtain inequalities between the tetraquark states and the corresponding heavy quarkonia in the following.

If we compare the so-obtained approximate upper bound in the fully-bottom sector with the earlier theoretical predictions listed in TableÂ 1, we find this value is indeed larger than all the model predictions except for that of Ref.Â Wang:2017jtz , which is calculated by means of QCD sum rules and has a large uncertainty.

V Possible Decays of Xbâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘X_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}}

The main difficulties in the experimental observation of fully-bottom tetraquark mesons are related to the production mechanisms and observation of the main decay modes. A very recent study discussed the production of the bâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground-state at the LHC, concluding that the bâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘bb\bar{b}\bar{b} is supposed to be very narrow and likely to be discovered Eichten:2017ual . Another recent studyÂ Vega-Morales:2017pmm also discussed the possible production of a narrow scalar resonance around 18âˆ¼19similar-to181918\sim 19 GeV at the LHC.777The decay of such resonance into four-lepton final state is also explored to disentangle whether it would be a tetraquark or something more exotic. In the following, we will discuss the decays of such a state and provide a rough estimate of its width. We will argue that the width is at least a few tens of MeV.

As shown in TableÂ 1, most of the models predict the ground-state fully-bottom tetraquark to be below the Î·bâ€‹Î·bsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘subscriptğœ‚ğ‘\eta_{b}\eta_{b} threshold. Because of this, one expects its width to be almost saturated by the following decay modes: 1) decays into final states containing a pair of bottom and anti-bottom quarks; 2) decays into hadrons of lighter flavors. The former is dominated by one-gluon exchange, while the latter should be dominated by two gluons. FigureÂ 2 shows an example of the decay into a pair of open-bottom mesons. Because the gluons are at the scale of mbsubscriptğ‘šğ‘m_{b}, one expects the first type of decays to dominate over the second. As it is not an easy task to calculate partial decay widths into given exclusive decay modes, in the following we provide a rough estimate of the inclusive decay width of the Xbâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘X_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}} ground-state based on the first decay mode.

The inclusive width of the Xbâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘X_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}} into final states with a pair of bğ‘b and bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\bar{b} quarks can be described as a two-step process triggered by a transition operator ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T} as

As a result, only the second factor (ğ’¯1subscriptğ’¯1\mathcal{T}_{1}) in the above equation matters.

The previous width (of the order of a few tens of MeV) is large enough to make the resonance observable. Our estimate of Eq. Despite of this, the multi-lepton final states are expected to provide a clean signal with a low background. The ideal place to look for the decays of Eq.Â (30) is the Large Hadron Collider experiments, where the Higgs boson cross section was measured by reconstructing a four-lepton final stateÂ cms:2015yvw . VI Summary

We calculated the bâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground-state energy in terms of two different approximations for the tetraquark wave function. They were used to simplify the solution of the four-body problem.

In the first case, we provided an evaluation of the bâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground-state energy in an NREFT at the LO, where the potential is an OGE-induced color Coulomb potential. A nice feature of our approach is that the color wave function is completely given by |3Â¯12â€‹334;11234âŸ©ketsubscriptÂ¯312subscript334subscript11234\left|\bar{\textbf{3}}_{12}\textbf{3}_{34};\textbf{1}_{1234}\right\rangle at the LO, and its mixing with |612â€‹6Â¯34;11234âŸ©ketsubscript612subscriptÂ¯634subscript11234\left|\textbf{6}_{12}\bar{\textbf{6}}_{34};\textbf{1}_{1234}\right\rangle only occurs at higher orders. The solution of the four-body problem was simplified by making use of the symmetries introduced by Hylleraas and Ore in their study of polyelectrons, namely the bound states of two electrons and positrons. In our specific case, one of the above mentioned symmetries could be expressed as Ïˆspatialâ€‹(bâ€‹b)=Ïˆspatialâ€‹(bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯)subscriptğœ“spatialğ‘ğ‘subscriptğœ“spatialÂ¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘\psi_{\textrm{spatial}}(bb)=\psi_{\textrm{spatial}}(\bar{b}\bar{b}), where Ïˆspatialâ€‹(bâ€‹b)subscriptğœ“spatialğ‘ğ‘\psi_{\textrm{spatial}}(bb) and Ïˆspatialâ€‹(bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯)subscriptğœ“spatialÂ¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘\psi_{\textrm{spatial}}(\bar{b}\bar{b}) are the spatial wave functions of the bâ€‹bğ‘ğ‘bb and bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘\bar{b}\bar{b} systems, respectively. Thanks to this, the four-body problem was simplified by reducing the number of integration variables. In the second case, we calculated the bâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground-state energy in a relativized diquark model. This model is characterized by OGE plus a confining potential. In the diquark model, the effective degree of freedom of the diquark, describing two strongly correlated quarks with no internal spatial excitations, is introduced. Tetraquark mesons are then obtained as two-body diquark-antidiquark bound states. Our results in both approachesâ€”NREFT at LO (18.72Â±0.02plus-or-minus18.720.0218.72\pm 0.02Â GeV) and relativized diquark model (18.75Â GeV)â€”only differ by a few tens of MeV, and suggests the existence of a bâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘bb\bar{b}\bar{b} bound-state below the Î·bâ€‹Î·bsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘subscriptğœ‚ğ‘\eta_{b}\eta_{b} threshold.

We also derived a set of approximate inequalities for the binding energies of the fully-heavy tetraquarks in terms of those of various heavy quarkonia. Instead of giving the values of the ground-state energies of the states of interest, the inequalities provide upper bounds on them. As expected, our LO NREFT and relativized diquark model results on the Xbâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘X_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}} ground-state mass satisfy the corresponding inequality.

Finally, we discussed the possible decay modes of the lowest fully-heavy tetraquarks and estimated the decay width of the ground state bâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘bb\bar{b}\bar{b} to be of ğ’ªâ€‹(50â€‹MeV)ğ’ª50MeV\mathcal{O}(50~{}\text{MeV}). We hope our results might provide useful references in the search for fully-heavy tetraquarks in ongoing LHC experiments. In particular, we suggest searching for the lowest Xbâ€‹bâ€‹bÂ¯â€‹bÂ¯subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘ğ‘Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘X_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}} in the relevant center-of-mass energy region around 18.7Â GeV in the final states of four leptons or a pair of bottom hadrons such as Bâ€‹BÂ¯ğµÂ¯ğµB\bar{B}, Î›bâ€‹Î›Â¯bsubscriptÎ›ğ‘subscriptÂ¯Î›ğ‘\Lambda_{b}\bar{\Lambda}_{b}, Îbâ€‹ÎÂ¯bsubscriptÎğ‘subscriptÂ¯Îğ‘\Xi_{b}\bar{\Xi}_{b}, Î£bâ€‹Î£Â¯bsubscriptÎ£ğ‘subscriptÂ¯Î£ğ‘\Sigma_{b}\bar{\Sigma}_{b} and Î©bâ€‹Î©Â¯bsubscriptÎ©ğ‘subscriptÂ¯Î©ğ‘\Omega_{b}\bar{\Omega}_{b},
